help.title: Help & Documentation
help.intro: The Meta Tags Preview Tool lets you see how your website links appear on social media platforms before you share them.
help.step1: Enter any website URL in the input field
help.step2: Click "Preview" to fetch Open Graph and Twitter Card meta tags
help.step3: Edit tags manually to test different combinations
help.step4: See real-time previews for Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn
help.tip2: Some sites may block automated fetchers
help.tip3: HTTP sites may have mixed content warnings in previews
help.imagesExplanation: If preview images don't appear, it's usually due to:
help.corsExplanation: Many websites prevent their images from being embedded on other sites for security reasons. This is controlled by CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) policies.
help.solution1: Use manual input to specify image URLs
help.solution2: Try uploading the image to a public CDN or image host
help.solution3: Check if the original website has CORS restrictions
help.solution4: Use absolute URLs (starting with https:// or http://)
help.practice4: Avoid hotlinking images from sites with strict CORS policies
help.titleTip3: Include your brand name when relevant
help.ogTip3: Keep text on images minimal and readable
help.exportIntro: Click the "Export as PNG" button to download a screenshot of your preview. This is useful for:
help.exportUse1: Sharing with your team or clients
help.limitation1: Images with CORS restrictions may not appear in export
help.limitation2: Some dynamic content may not render correctly
help.limitation3: Export quality depends on browser rendering
help.faq1q: Why don't images from some websites appear?
help.faq1a: Many websites configure CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) policies that prevent images from being embedded on other sites. This is a security feature. You can manually enter image URLs or use images from your own server.
help.faq2a: Yes! Both http:// and https:// URLs are supported. However, HTTPS is recommended for security.
help.faq3q: Why does the export PNG show broken images?
help.faq3a: This happens when images have CORS restrictions. The browser can display them but cannot export them to canvas. Try using a different image URL or hosting the image on a CORS-friendly server.
help.faq4a: The previews are based on official Open Graph and Twitter Card specifications and closely match how content appears on each platform. However, platforms may update their designs, so there may be slight variations.
help.needMoreHelpDesc: Have questions, suggestions, or found a bug? We'd love to hear from you!
